column1: So the woodman at last agreed to sell Thumbling to the strangers for a large piece of gold. "Where do you like to sit?" said one of them. "Oh! put me on the rim of your hat
column2: that will be a nice gallery for me; I can walk about there
column3: and see the country as we go along." So they did as he wished; and when Thumbling had taken leave of his father
column4: they carried him away with them. They journeyed on till it began to be dusky
column5: and then the little man said
column7: I'm tired." So the man took off his hat and set him down on a clod of earth in a ploughed field by the side of the road
column8: But Thumbling ran about amongst the furrows
column9: and at last slipped into a mouse-hole. "Good-night
column11: said he, I'm off! mind and look sharp after me the next time."
